En la Parte 2/4 de nuestra revisi√≥n cr√≠tica de SR, discutimos los errores en la famosa prueba de frente de onda esf√©rico de Einstein. En √∫ltima instancia, argumentamos que la Ley de Propagaci√≥n de la Luz (A2) no es invariante de Lorentz, contrariamente a las afirmaciones de Einstein. El error es sutil.

Dificultades aparentes en la RS y el Intento de Resoluci√≥n de Einstein
En el art√≠culo anterior (Parte 1/4) revisamos los supuestos b√°sicos de la RS, representados en los supuestos que llamamos (A1) y (A2).

(A1) que las leyes de la f√≠sica son las mismas en todos los marcos de referencia no acelerados, es decir, si \(K'\) es un sistema de coordenadas que se mueve uniformemente (y sin rotaci√≥n) con respecto a un sistema de coordenadas \(K\), entonces los fen√≥menos naturales se ejecutan su curso con respecto a \(K'\) seg√∫n exactamente las mismas leyes que con respecto a \(K\).
(A2) que la luz en el vac√≠o se propaga a lo largo de l√≠neas rectas con velocidad constante \(c = 300.000 ~km/sec\).

La conjunci√≥n \((A12):=(A1) \wedge (A2)\) conduce a dificultades intelectuales, como admite el propio Einstein. Pero estas dificultades son s√≥lo incompatibilidades aparentes seg√∫n Einstein que se resuelven postulando las transformaciones de Lorentz. La afirmaci√≥n de que las f√≥rmulas de Lorentz resuelven todas las dificultades aparentes en (A12) se deriva de dos afirmaciones:

Afirmaci√≥n (i): que los marcos inerciales \(K, K'\) est√°n relacionados por transformaciones de Lorentz.
Afirmaci√≥n (ii): que la ley de propagaci√≥n de la luz (A2) es invariante de Lorentz. Es decir. si (A2) se cumple en \(K\) , entonces (A2) se cumple en cada traducci√≥n de Lorentz \(K‚Ä≤=\lambda.K\).

La cuesti√≥n clave es verificar si (A2) realmente se deriva de las Reivindicaciones (i) y (ii). Este es el tema del argumento del frente de onda esf√©rico de Einstein que examinamos a continuaci√≥n.


Cr√≠tica de la Prueba de la Compatibilidad de (A12) de Einstein con las Transformaciones de Lorentz
Fuimos llevados a revisar la RS de Einstein leyendo los art√≠culos de S.J. Crothers y R. Bryant, que alegan que la prueba de ondas esf√©ricas de Einstein contiene errores significativos.
El argumento de Einstein busca derivar la afirmaci√≥n (ii) como una consecuencia matem√°tica de la afirmaci√≥n (i). El punto de partida es la propiedad fundamental de las transformaciones de Lorentz, que la expresi√≥n cuadr√°tica \[x^2+y^2+z^2 = c^2 t^2\] es invariante con respecto a las transformaciones de Lorentz. En otras palabras, el cono nulo \(N\) es Lorentz covariant. As√≠ si \[(\xi, \eta, \zeta, \tau)=\lambda. (x,y,z,t)\] para una transformada de Lorentz \(\lambda\), entonces tenemos

[Eq1] \[\xi^2 + \eta^2+\zeta^2 = c^2 \tau^2.\]

Pero, ¬øqu√© representa la expresi√≥n [Eq1]?
Aqu√≠ est√° el primer error de Einstein: su argumento identifica err√≥neamente [Eq1] con ‚Äúla ecuaci√≥n de una esfera‚Äù. El error es sutil. Pero el hecho es que [Eq1] es estrictamente hablando un cono tridimensional en las cuatro variables independientes \(\xi, \eta, \zeta, \tau\). De hecho, el cono contiene muchos subconjuntos bidimensionales esf√©ricos, pero nuestro punto es que una segunda ecuaci√≥n independiente es necesaria para especificar estas esferas. ¬°Y estas ecuaciones independientes no pueden elegirse Lorent invariablemente!
Penrose en su libro de texto con Rindler es bastante cuidadoso aqu√≠. El enfoque de Penrose es proyectar [Eq1] y obtener una esfera proyectiva con una estructura conforme invariante de Lorentz definida de manera √∫nica.
Pero nuevamente debemos enfatizar que no existe una m√©trica can√≥nica invariante con respecto al grupo de Lorentz sobre la proyectivizaci√≥n. En otras palabras, la esfera nula tiene una estructura conforme invariante de Lorentz, pero no tiene una estructura riemanniana invariante de Lorentz.
Por ejemplo, la esfera redonda est√°ndar \(S\) centrada en el origen satisface simult√°neamente [Eq1] and additionally the equation \[\frac{1}{2}d(\xi^2+\eta^2+\zeta^2)=\xi d\xi+\eta d\eta +\zeta d\zeta=0.\] En resumen, la esfera redonda requiere que dos formas cuadr√°ticas $ 2+2+^2$ y \(c^2\tau^2\) sean simult√°neamente constantes.
Esto nos lleva al segundo error de Einstein, que es no observar que la invariancia de Lorentz de la forma cuadr√°tica \(h=x^2+y^2+z^2-c^2t^2\) de ninguna manera implica la invariancia de Lorentz de \(h_1:=x^2+y^2+z^2\) y \(h_2:=c^2 t^2\).
De hecho, las formas cuadr√°ticas \(h_1, h_2\) son degeneradas, con radicales no triviales \(rad(h_1)=\{x=y=z=0\}\) y \(rad(h_2)=\{t=0\}.\) La los radicales son subespacios lineales de \({\bf{R}}^4\). Pero si \(h_1, h_2\) son invariantes, entonces \(rad(h_1)\) y \(rad(h_2)\) tambi√©n son subespacios invariantes no triviales. Esto contradice el hecho de que la representaci√≥n lineal est√°ndar del grupo de Lorentz act√∫a irreduciblemente sobre \({\bf{R}}^4\).
Para resumir los dos errores en el famoso argumento de Einstein:

el cono \(\xi^2 + \eta^2+\zeta^2 = c^2 \tau^2\) se identifica err√≥neamente como la ecuaci√≥n de una esfera.
la invariancia de Lorentz de \(\xi^2 + \eta^2+\zeta^2 = c^2 \tau^2\) no implica la invariancia de Lorentz de las formas \(\xi^2 + \eta^2+\zeta^2\) y \(c^2 \tau^2\).

En otras palabras, la igualdad num√©rica entre \(\xi^2 + \eta^2+\zeta^2\) y \(c^2\tau^2\) siempre se mantiene, pero los valores reales alcanzados por las expresiones no son invariantes de Lorentz.
Nos estamos repitiendo porque este es un punto algo sutil que se pasa por alto f√°cilmente.


C√°lculos elementales en \({\bf{R}}^{1,1}\)
Para ilustrar las ideas anteriores, es conveniente examinar algunos c√°lculos elementales en dos variables. Por lo tanto, consideramos \({\bf{R}^2}\) con coordenadas \((x,t)\) y \((\xi, \tau)\).
Por conveniencia num√©rica establecemos \(c:=1\).
Por lo tanto, \(h=x^2-t^2\) es una forma cuadr√°tica en \({\bf{R}}^2\) invariante con respecto al grupo unidimensional de Lorentz \(G=SO(1,1)_0\) generado por \[a_\theta:=\begin{pmatrix} \cosh \theta & \sinh \theta \\
\sinh \theta & \cosh \theta
\end{pmatrix}\] por \(\theta\in {\bf{R}}\).
En dos dimensiones, el cono nulo \[N=\{x^2-t^2=0\}\] se proyecta a una esfera de dimensi√≥n \(0\) que consta de dos puntos proyectivos representados por las l√≠neas afines \(x-t=0\) y $ x+t=0$.
La esfera redonda \(0\)-dimensional \(\{x^2=1\}\) consta de dos vectores en el cono nulo, a saber, \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1\end{pmatrix}, ~~~\begin {pmatrix} -1 \\ 1\end{pmatrix}.\]
Si trasladamos estos vectores por \(a_\theta\), encontramos la traducci√≥n \[\begin{pmatrix} \xi \\ \tau \end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix} \cosh \theta+\sinh \theta \\ \cosh \theta+\sinh \theta \end{pmatrix}~~\text{y} \begin{pmatrix} -\cosh \theta+\sinh \theta \\ \cosh \theta-\sinh \theta \end{pmatrix}.\]
Pero evidentemente \[\xi^2 \neq x^2=1^2=1\] y \[\tau^2 \neq t^2=1\] cuando \(\theta\neq 0\). As√≠, las formas cuadr√°ticas \(h_1=x^2\) y \(h_2=t^2\) no son_ \(a_\theta\)-invariantes. Asimismo encontramos que la imagen de la esfera unitaria \(x^2=1\) no corresponde a una esfera espacial en coordenadas \((\xi, \tau)\).
Estos c√°lculos triviales tienen el efecto de falsificar la supuesta invariancia de Lorentz de las ondas de luz esf√©ricas. Sin embargo, la ‚Äúpendiente‚Äù de \(\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1\end{pmatrix}\) y \[a_\theta.\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1\end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix} \cosh \theta+\sinh \theta \\ \cosh \theta+\sinh \theta \end{pmatrix}\] es id√©nticamente igual a \(c=1\) de acuerdo con (A2).
Para ilustrar mejor los comentarios anteriores sobre la inexistencia de par√°metros can√≥nicos en \(N\), considere que para cualquier funci√≥n mon√≥tona \(C^1\) \[ f: {\bf{R}} \to {\bf{R}} \] obtenemos una curva \[\epsilon(t)=\epsilon_f(t)=\begin{pmatrix} f(t) \ \ f(t) \end{pmatrix}=f(t) \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}\] para \(t\in {\bf{R}}\).
Entonces \(\epsilon_f(t)\) se apoya en una l√≠nea recta en \(N\), y se puede decir que el ‚Äúfot√≥n‚Äù \(\epsilon_f\) se propaga en l√≠nea recta con velocidad constante \(c=1\).
Podr√≠a decirse que \(\epsilon_f\) no es uniforme en el par√°metro \(t\), pero argumentamos que no existe una definici√≥n invariante de Lorentz de ‚Äúpar√°metro uniforme‚Äù en el cono nulo.
Esto est√° relacionado con nuestra discusi√≥n en la Parte 1 sobre el intento de Levi-Civita de derivar una ecuaci√≥n geod√©sica para la propagaci√≥n de la luz, es decir, la hip√≥tesis de que la luz viaja con aceleraci√≥n cero. Razonamos que esta es una hip√≥tesis adicional arbitraria, y no una consecuencia de los supuestos formales (A12).
En las Partes 3/4 y 4/4 restantes de este art√≠culo, consideramos las ecuaciones de onda homog√©neas y las transformaciones de Lorentz. Como hemos indicado previamente, encontramos que (A12) es incompatible con tanto los modelos de luz de onda como de part√≠culas.

text:
Supuestos de SR
Comenzamos con la introducci√≥n de Einstein a su teor√≠a de la Relatividad Especial (SR):

La elaboraci√≥n de estas dificultades intelectuales que surgen de esta aparentemente ‚Äúley simple‚Äù es el tema de nuestra discusi√≥n hoy.
¬øCu√°les son estas dificultades? Es decir, reconciliar los siguientes supuestos axiom√°ticos de la SR:

Einstein alega que estas dificultades son s√≥lo incompatibilidades aparentes, todas las cuales se reconcilian al postular f√≥rmulas de Lorentz-Fitzgerald para contracciones de longitud y dilataciones de tiempo.
La afirmaci√≥n de que las f√≥rmulas de Lorentz reconcilian estas dificultades contiene dos afirmaciones:

Examinamos cr√≠ticamente estas afirmaciones a continuaci√≥n. En lo que sigue, abordaremos los modelos de luz tanto de onda como de part√≠cula. En √∫ltima instancia, argumentamos que (A12) es incompatible con ambos modelos, es decir, incompatible con el principio de complementariedad de Bohr.


Transformaciones de Lorentz
El √°lgebra lineal del espacio de Minkowski y las transformaciones de Lorentz juegan un papel definitivo en SR.
Las transformaciones de Lorentz en el contexto de SR se pueden definir como el grupo de transformaciones lineales \(\lambda: {\bf{R}}^{4} \to {\bf{R}}^4\) que satisfacen \(\lambda^* (h)=h\) donde \(h=ds^2\) es la forma cuadr√°tica de Minkowski-Lorentz $\(h:=ds^2=-c^2dt^2+dx^2+dy^2+dz^2.\) ps Aqu√≠ \(c\) es la velocidad luminal constante en el vac√≠o postulada por (A2).
La invariancia de Lorentz de \(h\) dice que \[\xi^2+\eta^2+\zeta^2-c^2 \tau^2\] es num√©ricamente igual a \[x^2+y^2+z^ 2-c^2 t^2\] para cada transformada de Lorentz \(\lambda\) que satisface \[(\xi, \eta, \zeta, \tau)=\lambda.(x,y,z,t).\] Por tanto, se supone que \(h\) es un invariante escalar para todos los observadores inerciales.
Se plante√≥ la hip√≥tesis del grupo de transformaciones de Lorentz como un intento de explicar el resultado nulo observado del experimento del interfer√≥metro de Michelson-Morley. El experimento estaba destinado a medir las variaciones de la velocidad de la luz en relaci√≥n con el √©ter. No se descubrieron tales variaciones, y se postul√≥ que las coordenadas habituales de espacio y tiempo \((x,y,z,t)\) y \((\xi, \eta, \zeta, \tau)\) de dos observadores inerciales $K $ y \(K'\), respectivamente, no estaban relacionados por transformaciones de Galileo, sino por las f√≥rmulas de Lorentz-Fitzgerald. Incre√≠blemente y contrariamente a todas las expectativas, el brazo material del interfer√≥metro se contrajo en la direcci√≥n del movimiento y simult√°neamente el par√°metro de tiempo se contrajo en la misma proporci√≥n, a saber, el llamado factor beta \(\beta = 1/\sqrt{1-v ^2/c^2}\).


Unicidad de las formas cuadr√°ticas invariantes de Lorentz
Es un resultado interesante de Elton y Arminjon [insertar referencia] que la forma de Minkowski \(h\) es la √∫nica forma cuadr√°tica invariante de Lorentz en \({\bf{R}}^4\) m√≥dulo de homotecia. Esto tiene una consecuencia √∫til para la ecuaci√≥n de onda homog√©nea, como veremos m√°s adelante.


Espacio Minkowski y Cono Nulo
Ahora decimos algo sobre el modelo fot√≥nico de luz como se trata en el libro [III.XI.6, pp.301]. If light satisfies (A2) de Levi-Civita, luego en un marco de referencia \(K\), la luz es algo \[\gamma(t)=(x(t),y(t), z(t))\] que viaja a trav√©s del espacio con el tiempo, y cuya velocidad \(\gamma'\) si pudiera medirse materialmente como una funci√≥n de \(t\) satisfar√≠a - [Eq1] \[||\gamma'||^2=(dx/dt)^2+(dy/dt)^2+(dz/dt)^2=c^2.\]
Por lo tanto, se argumenta que las trayectorias de la luz est√°n restringidas al cono nulo \[N:=\{h=0\} \subset {\bf{R}}^4\] de la m√©trica \(h\) de Minkowski. Obviamente, el cono nulo \(N\) es el subespacio invariante de Lorentz, y est√° definido por la ecuaci√≥n \[x^2+y^2+z^2=c^2 t^2\] en cualquier marco de referencia \(K\) con coordenadas \(( x,y,z,t)\).


¬øQu√© dice [Eq1] sobre la Propagaci√≥n de la Luz?
Nuevamente, si la luz es algo \(\gamma\) que viaja, entonces [Eq1] implica que la velocidad de \(\gamma\) es id√©nticamente igual a \(c\) medida en \(K\).
Pero la velocidad de \(\gamma\) es independiente de la direcci√≥n de movimiento de \(\gamma\) restringida a \(N\).
La suposici√≥n de Einstein (A2) intenta prescribir la velocidad asumiendo que la propagaci√≥n es a lo largo de l√≠neas rectas con velocidad constante. Pero, de nuevo, la velocidad todav√≠a est√° indeterminada, ya que la direcci√≥n de la part√≠cula no est√° determinada por su pertenencia a una l√≠nea recta.
Proponemos que la direcci√≥n y la magnitud no est√°n determinadas √∫nicamente por (A2). Adem√°s, las transformaciones de Lorentz no satisfacen la afirmaci√≥n (ii), es decir, (A2) no es invariante de Lorentz.
El problema es que la imagen del colegial de la propagaci√≥n de la luz en el vac√≠o es una perspectiva riemanniana. Pero esta perspectiva riemanniana no es invariante de Lorentz. De hecho, en la geometr√≠a de Riemann, si una part√≠cula viaja en l√≠nea recta y con velocidad constante, entonces la propagaci√≥n de la part√≠cula, es decir, su posici√≥n en funci√≥n del tiempo, est√° determinada de forma √∫nica. Sin embargo, en la geometr√≠a lorentziana, una part√≠cula que viaja en l√≠nea recta a lo largo del cono nulo siempre tendr√° una velocidad constante, independientemente de su trayectoria. Suponiendo que la trayectoria se limita a una l√≠nea recta, a√∫n queda la cuesti√≥n de la posici√≥n de la part√≠cula en funci√≥n del tiempo. El problema es que la uniformidad de la propagaci√≥n en l√≠nea recta no tiene sentido en el cono nulo de la geometr√≠a lorentziana.


La Ecuaci√≥n Variacional de Levi-Civita es Trivial en el Cono Nulo
Aqu√≠ presentamos el enfoque de Levi-Civita como se representa en su excelente libro de texto. Levi-Civita modifica algo (A2) afirmando que ‚Äúla propagaci√≥n de la luz es rectil√≠nea, uniforme y con velocidad \(c\)‚Äú.
El t√©rmino ‚Äúuniforme‚Äù no aparece en la formulaci√≥n de Einstein de (A2), aunque habla de la suposici√≥n oculta de que los rayos de luz tienen un par√°metro can√≥nico que describe el movimiento uniforme del rayo de luz. Los comentarios anteriores est√°n directamente relacionados con la caracterizaci√≥n de la √≥ptica geom√©trica de Levi-Civita en las siguientes dos ecuaciones (ver [III.XI.16]):

[Eq2] \[\delta \int ds=0 \] y
[Eq3] \[ds^2=0.\]

La primera ecuaci√≥n [Eq2] dice que la derivada variacional del funcional \(\gamma \mapsto \int_\gamma ds\) desaparece en las trayectorias de la luz, y la segunda ecuaci√≥n [Eq3] dice que la trayectoria est√° restringida al cono nulo.
En el entorno de Riemann donde \(ds\) es definida positiva, la ecuaci√≥n [Eq2] es esencialmente equivalente a la ecuaci√≥n geod√©sica \(\nabla_{\gamma'} \gamma'=0\).
Sin embargo en el escenario lorentziano encontramos [Eq2]reduces to \(0=0\) on the null cone \(N\). Thus the usual Riemannian \(ds>0\) argument does establish the corresponding ‚Äúgeodesic‚Äù equation on \(N\). This is acknowledged in Levi-Civita [III.XI.14], but Levi-Civita argues that zero length geodesics are limits of Riemannian geodesics (\(ds>0\)) y que ‚Äúhay un proceso de paso al l√≠mite (en condiciones de completa regularidad anal√≠tica) desde las geod√©sicas ordinarias‚Äù. Levi-Civita sostiene que la ecuaci√≥n variacional [Eq2] de alguna manera ‚Äúimplica‚Äù la ecuaci√≥n de tipo geod√©sico \(\nabla_{\gamma'} \gamma'=0\) para los rayos de luz.
Nuestro punto de vista es que \(\nabla_{\gamma'} \gamma'=0\) es una hip√≥tesis independiente, y de ninguna manera una consecuencia formal de [Eq2]. Esto est√° relacionado con nuestra afirmaci√≥n de que, contrariamente a las afirmaciones de Levi-Civita, la ecuaci√≥n variacional [Eq2] en \(N=\{ds=0\}\) es trivial. En t√©rminos geom√©tricos riemannianos, encontramos l√≠neas rectas en \(N\) que no tienen parametrizaciones can√≥nicas, ni siquiera afines. Esto revela una clara distinci√≥n entre las rectas riemannianas que s√≠ tienen un par√°metro can√≥nico de longitud de arco \(ds\), y las l√≠neas nulas \(\ell \subset N\) que no admiten el par√°metro can√≥nico \(ds\) de longitud de arco excepto el trivial \(ds=0\) .

title: Foundations of Special Relativity and Light Propagation in Vacuum. A Critical Review (3/4).
text:
In Part 3/4 of our critical review of SR we examine the homogeneous wave equation and its properties under Lorentz transformations.

Homogeneous Wave Equation, Lorentz Transformations and SR
In Parts 1 and 2 of this series we focussed on Minkowski space, linear algebra of Lorentz transformations, and the null cone. These discussions were mainly based on the photon model of light.
In Part 3 we consider the wave model of light, and specifically properties of Lorentz transformations and the homogeneous wave equation (HWE).
Briefly, Einstein‚Äôs attempted proof of Claims (i) and (ii) that the Lorentz formulae resolves all the apparent contradictions of (A12) is based on the idea of light propagating a constant speed \(c\) which is identical for all observers. From Einstein‚Äôs spherical wavefront argument, we see that Einstein understood (A12) as implying that light pulses propagate in geometrically spherical wave fronts in every inertial reference frame \(K\). In terms of the HWE this implies that there exists a Lorentz invariant class of radial solutions to (HWE). As we discuss below, radial solutions exist canonically for any single reference frame \(K\). However the arguments from Parts 1 and 2 demonstrate that no Lorentz invariant set of radial solutions can exist simultaneously for all reference frames \(K'\).


d‚ÄôAlembert \(\square\) is Unique Lorentz Invariant 2nd Order Linear Differential Operator
In Part 1 we briefly mentioned an interesting result of Elton-Arminjon on the Minkowski metric \[h=d\xi^2 + d\eta^2 + d \zeta^2 - c^2 \tau^2\] being the unique Lorentz invariant symmetric quadratic form on \({\bf{R}}^4\) (modulo homothety). Their proof has useful corollary in terms of the HWE.
Let \(\square\) be d‚ÄôAlembert‚Äôs wave operator. Then \(\square\) is a second order homogeneous linear differential operator, in coordinates having the form \[\square = \frac{\partial^2}{\partial \xi^2} +\frac{\partial^2}{\partial \eta^2}+\frac{\partial^2}{\partial \zeta^2}-\frac{1}{c^2}\frac{\partial^2}{\partial \tau^2}.\]
Informally we view \(\square\) as essentially dual to Minkowski‚Äôs form \(h\). Somewhat more rigorously, we find Elton-Arminjon‚Äôs argument proves the following:

Lemma: Let \(C\) be the algebra of polynomial functions on \({\bf{R}}^4\), and let \(\rho^*\) be the contragredient representation of the Lorentz group on \(C\). Then d‚ÄôAlembert‚Äôs wave operator \(\square\) is the unique Lorentz invariant second order linear differential operator on \(C\) modulo homothety.

It follows that Einstein‚Äôs Claim (i) that different inertial frames \(K, K'\) are related by Lorentz transformations also implies that d‚ÄôAlembert‚Äôs operator \(\square\) is essentially the unique second order operator defined simultaneously for all inertial observers. This means the HWE is the only Lorentz invariant second order equation on \({\bf{R}}^4\).
The Lorentz invariance of the HWE implies that solutions to the HWE are Lorentz covariant. To be precise, if \(\phi=\phi(x,y,z,t)\) is a regular function satisfying the HWE, namely \[ \phi_{xx}+\phi_{yy}+\phi_{zz}-\frac{1}{c^2}\phi_{tt}=0, \] and if \(\lambda\) is a Lorentz transform with \[(\xi, \eta, \zeta, \tau)=\lambda.(x,y,z,t),\] then \[\phi':=\lambda^*(\phi)=\phi\circ\lambda^{-1}\] is again a solution of the HWE: \[\phi_{\xi \xi}+\phi_{\eta \eta}+\phi_{\zeta \zeta}-\frac{1}{c^2}\phi_{\tau \tau}=0.\] This is verified by elementary computation.
The above discussion is completely elementary. More significant is the interpretation of (A12) in terms of the HWE.


Radius is Not a Lorentz Invariant Variable
We understand (A12) as declaring that there exists a distinguished Lorentz invariant class of solutions to HWE which correspond to spherical light waves. However we argue that this contradicts the properties of HWE. Specifically there does not exist a Lorentz invariant set of radial solutions to the HWE.
Indeed the spatial radius variable \(r^2=x^2+y^2+z^2\) is not a Lorentz invariant variable. This was discussed in Part 2, but we can give another explanation in terms of Lie groups.
In group theoretic terms, a solution \(\phi=\phi(x,t)\) of HWE is said to be radial by an observer \(K\) iff \(\phi(Ax,t)=\phi(x,t)\) for every rigid motion \(A\in SO(3)\) in the space variables \(x,y,z\) of \(K\). Implicitly this requires a Lie group representation \(\rho\) of \(SO(3)\) into the Lorentz group \(G\simeq O(3,1)\). But this choice of maximal compact subgroup is noncanonical. Different inertial observers \(K, K'\) generally choose different orthogonal symmetry groups, e.g.¬†according to their own physical sum of squares formula \(\xi^2+\eta^2+\zeta^2\).
Of course the Minkowski form \(h\) is invariant and canonical, but any decomposition into ‚Äúspatial‚Äù and ‚Äútime‚Äù components requires arbitrary observer dependant choices, and these choices cannot be Lorentz invariant.
For example, while the open set of timelike vectors \(\{h(v) < 0\}\) is invariantly defined, there is no Lorentz invariant choice of timelike vector. Likewise among the spacelike set \(\{h(v)>0\}\) there is no Lorentz invariant choice of orthogonal three-dimensional frame.
Furthermore, for the motion of light pulses according to (A12) the Minkowski element vanishes identically, and the only canonical tensor element becomes the constant zero element. After a Lorentz change of variables we find a new solution \(\phi'\) as above, but this solution need not be radial in the inertial frame \(K'\). Indeed the rigid \(K\)-space motion \(A\) will not generally preserve the space coordinates \(\xi, \eta, \zeta\) of \(K'\). Thus we find \(A\)-motions nontrivially depend on the \(K'\)-time variable \(\tau\). This again reflects the nonexistence of a Lorentz invariant radius.


Conclusion
This concludes our mathematical analysis of the foundations of SR, especially Einstein‚Äôs Assumptions (A12) and his attempted resolution via Lorentz formulae and Claims (i) and (ii).
Ultimately the Lorentz transformations do not have the necessary properties to maintain (A12). The so-called Law of Propagation of Light (A2) is not a Lorentz invariant law, and therefore does not itself satisfy the Principle of Restricted Relativity as supposed by Einstein in his Assumption (A1).
In our final Part 4 of this series, we present some potential objections to our arguments and attempt to anticipate some criticisms. However we must maintain that all the above arguments are mathematically correct. Any constructive comments or feedback are welcome at the author‚Äôs address jhmLabs &&a.t.&& gmail d&&0t&& com.

title: Foundations of Special Relativity and Light Propagation in Vacuum. A Critical Review (1/4).
text:
Assumptions of SR
We begin with Einstein‚Äôs introduction to his theory of Special Relativity (SR):
‚ÄúThere is hardly a simpler law in physics than that according to which light is propagated in empty space. Every child at school knows, or believes he knows, that this propagation takes place in straight lines with velocity \(c=300,000 ~km/sec\). Who would imagine that this simple law has plunged the conscientiously thoughtful physicist into the greatest intellectual difficulties?‚Äù
The elaboration of these intellectual difficulties arising from this seemingly ‚Äúsimple law‚Äù is the subject of our discussion today.
What are these difficulties? Namely to reconcile the following axiomatic assumptions of SR:

(A1) that the laws of physics are the same in all nonaccelerated reference frames, i.e.¬†if \(K'\) is a coordinate system moving uniformly (and devoid of rotation) with respect to a coordinate system \(K\), then natural phenomena run their course with respect to \(K'\) according to exactly the same laws as with respect to \(K\).
(A2) that light in vacuum propagates along straight lines with constant velocity \(c\approx 300,000 ~km/sec\).



Apparent Difficulties in (A12)
The difficulties arise from the conjunction (A1) and (A2), which we denote by (A12). \[(A12):=(A1) \wedge (A2).\]
If Assumption (A2) is indeed a Law of nature, then according to (A1) this law of propagation should be invariant in every inertial reference frame. But (A12) appears contradictory to the principles of classical mechanics, e.g.¬†Fizeau law of addition of velocities.
Einstein alleges that these difficulties are only apparent incompatibilities, all of which are reconciled by postulating Lorentz-Fitzgerald formulae for length contractions and time dilations.
The assertion that the Lorentz formulae reconcile these difficulties contains two claims:


that inertial frames \(K, K'\) are related by Lorentz transformations.


that the law of propagation of light (A2) is Lorentz invariant. I.e. if \((A2)\) is satisfied in \(K\), then \((A2)\) is satisfied in every Lorentz translate \(K'=\lambda.K\).


We critically examine these claims below. In what follows we will address both wave and particle models of light. Ultimately we argue that (A12) is incompatible with both models, i.e.¬†incompatible with Bohr‚Äôs complementarity principle.


Lorentz Transformations
The linear algebra of Minkowski space and Lorentz transformations plays a definitive role in SR.
Lorentz transformations in the setting of SR can be defined as the group of linear transformations \(\lambda: {\bf{R}}^{4} \to {\bf{R}}^4\) which satisfy \(\lambda^*(h)=h\) where \(h=ds^2\) is the Minkowski-Lorentz quadratic form \[h:=ds^2=-c^2dt^2+dx^2+dy^2+dz^2.\] Here \(c\) is the constant luminal velocity in vacuum posited by (A2).
The Lorentz invariance of \(h\) says \[\xi^2+\eta^2+\zeta^2-c^2 \tau^2\] is numerically equal to \[x^2+y^2+z^2-c^2 t^2\] for every Lorentz transform \(\lambda\) satisfying \[(\xi, \eta, \zeta, \tau)=\lambda.(x,y,z,t).\] Thus it is assumed that \(h\) is a scalar invariant for all inertial observers.
The group of Lorentz transformations was hypothesized as an attempt to explain the observed null result of Michelson-Morley‚Äôs interferometer experiment. The experiment was intended to measure variations of the speed of light relative to the aether. No such variations were discovered, and it was postulated that the usual space and time coordinates \((x,y,z,t)\) and \((\xi, \eta, \zeta, \tau)\) of two inertial observers \(K\) and \(K'\), respectively, were not related by Galilean transformations, but related by the Lorentz-Fitzgerald formulae. Incredibly and contrary to all expectations, the material arm of the interferometer contracted in the direction of motion and simultaneously the time parameter was contracted by the same ratio, namely the so-called beta factor \(\beta = 1/\sqrt{1-v^2/c^2}\).


Uniqueness of Lorentz Invariant Quadratic Forms
It‚Äôs interesting result of Elton and Arminjon [insert ref] that Minkowski‚Äôs form \(h\) is the only Lorentz invariant quadratic form on \({\bf{R}}^4\) modulo homothety. This has useful consequence for the homogeneous wave equation, as we discuss below.


Minkowski Space and Null Cone
Now we say something about the photon model of light as treated in Levi-Civita‚Äôs book [III.XI.6, pp.301]. If light satisfies (A2), then in a reference frame \(K\), light is something \[\gamma(t)=(x(t),y(t),z(t))\] that travels through space with time, and whose velocity \(\gamma'\) if it could be materially measured as a function of \(t\) would satisfy - [Eq1] \[||\gamma'||^2=(dx/dt)^2+(dy/dt)^2+(dz/dt)^2=c^2.\]
Thus it is argued that light trajectories are constrained to the null cone \[N:=\{h=0\} \subset {\bf{R}}^4\] of Minkowski‚Äôs metric \(h\). Obviously the null cone \(N\) is Lorentz invariant subspace, and defined by the equation \[x^2+y^2+z^2=c^2 t^2\] in any reference frame \(K\) with coordinates \((x,y,z,t)\).


What does [Eq1] say about the Propagation of Light?
Again if light is something \(\gamma\) that travels, then [Eq1] implies the speed of \(\gamma\) is identically equal to \(c\) as measured in \(K\).
But the speed of \(\gamma\) is independant of the direction of motion of \(\gamma\) constrained to \(N\).
Einstein‚Äôs assumption (A2) attempts to prescribe the velocity by assuming the propagation is along straight lines with constant speed. But again the velocity is still underdetermined, since the direction of the particle is not determined by it‚Äôs belonging to a straight line.
We are proposing that the direction and magnitude are not determined uniquely by (A2). Moreover the Lorentz transformations do not satisfy Claim (ii), i.e.¬†(A2) is not Lorentz invariant.
The problem is that the schoolboy‚Äôs image of the propagation of light in vacuum is a Riemannian perspective. But this Riemannian perspective is not Lorentz invariant. Indeed in Riemannian geometry, if a particle is travelling in a straight line and with constant velocity, then the propagation of the particle, namely it‚Äôs position as a function of time, uniquely determined. However, in Lorentzian geometry, a particle which is travelling in a straight line along the null cone will always have a constant speed, regardless of its trajectory. Supposing that the trajectory is confined to a straight line, there still remains the question of the position of the particle as a function of time. The problem is that the of the straight line propagation is meaningless on the null cone of Lorentzian geometry.


Levi-Civita‚Äôs Variational Equation is Trivial on the Null Cone
Here we introduce Levi-Civita‚Äôs approach as represented in his excellent textbook. Levi-Civita modifies (A2) somewhat by asserting that ‚Äúthe propagation of light is rectilinear, uniform, and with velocity \(c\)‚Äú.
The term ‚Äúuniform‚Äù does not feature in Einstein‚Äôs formulation of (A2), although it speaks to the hidden assumption that the light rays have a canonical parameter describing the motion of the light ray. The above remarks are directly related to Levi-Civita‚Äôs characterization of geometric optics in the following two equations (see [III.XI.16]):

[Eq2] \[\delta \int ds=0 \] and
[Eq3] \[ds^2=0.\]

The first equation [Eq2] says the variational derivative of the functional \(\gamma \mapsto \int_\gamma ds\) vanishes on the light trajectories, and the second equation [Eq3] says the trajectory is constrained to the null cone.
In the Riemannian setting where \(ds\) is positive definite, the equation [Eq2] is essentially equivalent to the geodesic equation \(\nabla_{\gamma'} \gamma'=0\).
However in the Lorentzian setting we find [Eq2]reduces to \(0=0\) on the null cone \(N\). Thus the usual Riemannian \(ds>0\) argument does establish the corresponding ‚Äúgeodesic‚Äù equation on \(N\). This is acknowledged in Levi-Civita [III.XI.14], but Levi-Civita argues that zero length geodesics are limits of Riemannian geodesics (\(ds>0\)) and that ‚Äúthere is a process of passing to the limit (in conditions of complete analytical regularity) from ordinary geodesics‚Äù. Levi-Civita maintains that the variational equation [Eq2] somehow ‚Äúimplies‚Äù the geodesic-type equation \(\nabla_{\gamma'} \gamma'=0\) for light rays.
Our viewpoint is that \(\nabla_{\gamma'} \gamma'=0\) is an independant hypothesis, and by no means a formal consequence of [Eq2]. This is related to our contention that contrary to Levi-Civita‚Äôs claims, the variational equation [Eq2] on \(N=\{ds=0\}\) is trivial. In Riemannian geometric terms, we find straight lines on \(N\) have no canonical parameterizations, even affine. This reveals a clear distinction between Riemannian straight lines which do have a canonical arclength parameter \(ds\), and the null lines \(\ell \subset N\) which do not admit canonical \(ds\) arclength parameter except the trivial \(ds=0\).

In Part 4/4 of our critical review of SR we review the primary propositions of the previous three parts, and further consider some objections and responses to our arguments.
In Part 1,2,3 of this series, we have presented our critical mathematical review of the foundations of SR.
As we have discussed in previous Parts, our objections apply simultaneously to the wave and particle models of light. These objections will be elaborated below.

title: jhmartel.github.io
text:
1.
One might object that all our arguments reduce to the observation that spheres in the frame \(K\) are transformed to ellipsoids in \(K'\) as is well-known.
But we remind the reader that Lorentz contraction is assumed to affect material objects, even independantly of the nature of the material. So material spheres in \(K\) become material ellipsoids in \(K'\), where the eccentricity of the \(K'\)-ellipsoid is nontrivial and independant of the material nature of the sphere. However we respond that light spheres are immaterial and not themselves subject to Lorentz contraction. And indeed if light spheres were subject to the same contraction effects as material spheres, then (A2) would definitely be false.

title: jhmartel.github.io
text:
2.
Critics may object that (A12) only requires the consistent measurement of \(c\) in arbitrary reference frames \(K, K'\). This would replace the law (A2) with some rule of thumb for measurements.
But this immediately leads to a well-known experimental difficulty at the core of special relativity, namely the impossibility of measuring the one way speed of light. Indeed space and time measurements are always dependant on material objects and often non local, having sources and receivers separated by large distances. The impossibility of synchronizing non local clocks leads to the impossibility of measuring the one-way velocity of light. That all measurements of \(c\) only succeed in measuring the two way or ‚Äúround trip‚Äù velocities of light where source and receiver coincide is discussed in [Zhang 1997] and [Perez 2011]. See also Veritasium‚Äôs video ‚ÄúWhy the Speed of Light Can‚Äôt be Measured‚Äù.
Moreover in studying the two-way velocity of light, one needs further postulate that the velocity \(c\) is constant (uniform) throughout its two-way journey, as Einstein argued. But this assumption is admittedly arbitrary and unverifiable.

text:
3.
Wolfgang Rindler‚Äôs very interesting textbook attempts ‚Äúin spite of its historical and heuristic importance, [‚Ä¶] to de-emphasize the logical role of the law of light propagation [(A2)] as a pillar of special relativity.‚Äù
Rindler claims that ‚Äúa second axiom [(A2)] is needed only[!] to determine the value of a constant \(c\) of the dimensions of a velocity that occurs naturally in the theory. But this could come from any number of branches of physics ‚Äì we need only think of the energy formula \(E=mc^2\), or de Broglie‚Äôs velocity relation \(u v =c^2\).‚Äù
Rindler‚Äôs objection is interesting, and our response is simply that the above quoted formulas are equivalent to (A2), and not independant in any logical or physical sense.
The constant \(c\) is central to modern physics. But what is the definition of this constant? Clearly Einstein defines \(c\) as the speed of light (‚Äúceleritas‚Äù, or swiftness) en vacuo. But is Einstein silently introducing a new definition of \(c\) in his theory? What is the origin of defining \(c\) in vacuum?
Let us review history. The constant \(c\) was first formulated and estimated by Wilhelm Weber circa 1846, and even before J.C. Maxwell‚Äôs famous treatise. Weber further studied \(c\) with G. Kirchoff in the telegraphy equations. Here \(c\) is the speed of propagation of electrical signals in long thin wires of arbitrarily small resistance. But the Weber-Kirchoff definition of \(c\) is not equivalent to the \(c\) of Einstein‚Äôs special relativity. Einstein defines \(c\) as speed in vacuum, and Weber-Kirchoff define \(c\) as speed of signal propagation in a material conductive wire!
There does not appear any independant relation involving \(c\) en vacuo apart from Einstein‚Äôs (A2). Even the incredible Weber-Kohlrausch formula expressing \(c\) as ratio of electric and magnetic dielectric constants presumes a material medium, i.e.¬†the ratio is undefined in vacuum. Thus all formulas involving \(c\) (where \(c\) is Einstein‚Äôs speed of light in vacuum) are based essentially on some form of (A2), and the logical pillar remains unmoved.

4.
A fourth objection might criticize our argument for not properly accounting for the so-called wave-particle duality of light, e.g.¬†Bohr complementarity.
Our presentation has addressed both corpuscular and undulatory models, showing that (A12) is underdetermined in both cases. The incompatibility of (A12) with both the wave and particle model has been highlighted by A.K.T. Assis [Section 7.2.4, pp.133] from his ‚ÄúRelational Mechanics‚Äù:

‚Äúwe can only conclude that for Einstein the velocity of light is constant not only whatever the state of motion of the emitting body [source], but also whatever the state of motion of the receiving body (detector) and of the observer.‚Äù

For waves in physical medium, the velocity of emission is independant of the velocity of the source, since waves are transmitted by the medium and their velocities a property of the medium. Furthermore for both particles and waves, it is known that velocity is dependant on the velocity of the receiver.
According to (A2), light is postulated to exhibit properties unlike both waves and particles. Thus we argue that (A2) contradicts the supposed complementarity and wave-particle duality, i.e.¬†(A2) requires light to behave contrary to both the wave and particle interpretations.

Ecuaci√≥n de Onda Homog√©nea, Transformaciones de Lorentz y SR
En las Partes 1 y 2 de esta serie nos enfocamos en el espacio de Minkowski, el √°lgebra lineal de las transformaciones de Lorentz y el cono nulo. Estas discusiones se basaron principalmente en el modelo fot√≥nico de la luz.
En la Parte 3 consideramos el modelo ondulatorio de la luz, y espec√≠ficamente las propiedades de las transformaciones de Lorentz y la ecuaci√≥n de onda homog√©nea (EOH).
Brevemente, el intento de prueba de Einstein de las afirmaciones (i) y (ii) de que las f√≥rmulas de Lorentz resuelven todas las aparentes contradicciones de (A12) se basa en la idea de que la luz se propaga a una velocidad constante \(c\) que es id√©ntica para todos los observadores. Del argumento del frente de onda esf√©rico de Einstein, vemos que Einstein entendi√≥ que (A12) implica que los pulsos de luz se propagan en frentes de onda geom√©tricamente esf√©ricos en todos marcos de referencia inerciales \(K\). En t√©rminos de EOH, esto implica que existe una clase invariante de Lorentz de soluciones radiales para EOH. Como discutimos a continuaci√≥n, las soluciones radiales existen can√≥nicamente para cualquier marco de referencia √∫nico \(K\). Sin embargo, los argumentos de las Partes 1 y 2 demuestran que ning√∫n conjunto invariante de soluciones radiales de Lorentz puede existir simult√°neamente para todos los marcos de referencia \(K'\).


d‚ÄôAlembert cuadrado \(\square\) es un √∫nico operador diferencial lineal de segundo orden invariante de Lorentz
En la Parte 1 mencionamos brevemente un resultado interesante de Elton-Arminjon sobre la m√©trica de Minkowski \[h=d\xi^2 + d\eta^2 + d \zeta^2 - c^2 \tau^2\] siendo el √∫nica forma cuadr√°tica sim√©trica invariante de Lorentz en \({\bf{R}}^4\) (m√≥dulo de homotecia). Su prueba tiene un corolario √∫til en t√©rminos de EOH.
Sea \(\square\) el operador de onda de d‚ÄôAlembert. Entonces \(\square\) es un operador diferencial lineal homog√©neo de segundo orden, en coordenadas que tienen la forma \[\square = \frac{\partial^2}{\partial \xi^2} +\frac{\partial^2}{ \partial \eta^2}+\frac{\partial^2}{\partial \zeta^2}-\frac{1}{c^2}\frac{\partial^2 }{\partial \tau^2 }.\]
Informalmente vemos \(\square\) como esencialmente dual a la forma \(h\) de Minkowski. Algo m√°s riguroso, encontramos que el argumento de Elton-Arminjon prueba lo siguiente:

Lema: Sea \(C\) el √°lgebra de funciones polinomiales en \({\bf{R}}^4\), y sea \(\rho^*\) la representaci√≥n contragrediente del grupo de Lorentz en \(C\). Entonces, el operador de onda de d‚ÄôAlembert \(\square\) es el √∫nico operador diferencial lineal de segundo orden invariante de Lorentz en \(C\) m√≥dulo de homotecia.

De ello se deduce que la afirmaci√≥n de Einstein (i) de que diferentes marcos inerciales \(K, K'\) est√°n relacionados mediante transformaciones de Lorentz tambi√©n implica que el operador de d‚ÄôAlembert \(\square\) es esencialmente el √∫nico operador de segundo orden definido simult√°neamente para todos los observadores inerciales. Esto significa que EOH es la √∫nica ecuaci√≥n de segundo orden invariante de Lorentz en \({\bf{R}}^4\).
La invariancia de Lorentz del EOH implica que las soluciones del EOH son covariantes de Lorentz. Para ser precisos, si \(\phi=\phi(x,y,z,t)\) es una funci√≥n regular que satisface el HWE, a saber \[ \phi_{xx}+\phi_{yy}+\phi_{zz}-\frac{1}{c^2}\phi_{tt}=0, \] y si \(\lambda\) es una transformada de Lorentz con \[(\xi, \eta, \zeta, \tau)=\lambda.(x,y,z,t),\] entonces \[\phi':=\lambda^*(\phi)=\phi\circ\lambda^{-1}\] es nuevamente una soluci√≥n del EOH: \[\phi_{\xi \xi}+\phi_{\eta \eta}+\phi_{\zeta \zeta}-\frac{1}{c^2}\phi_{\tau \tau}=0.\] Esto se verifica mediante c√°lculo elemental.
La discusi√≥n anterior es completamente elemental. M√°s significativa es la interpretaci√≥n de (A12) en t√©rminos de EOH.


El radio no es una variable invariante de Lorentz
Entendemos que (A12) declara que existe una clase invariante distinguida de Lorentz de soluciones para EOH que corresponden a ondas de luz esf√©ricas. Sin embargo, argumentamos que esto contradice las propiedades de EOH. Espec√≠ficamente no existe un conjunto invariante de Lorentz de soluciones radiales para el EOH.
De hecho, la variable de radio espacial \(r^2=x^2+y^2+z^2\) no es una variable invariante de Lorentz. Esto se discuti√≥ en la Parte 2, pero podemos dar otra explicaci√≥n en t√©rminos de grupos de Lie.
En t√©rminos de teor√≠a de grupos, un observador dice que una soluci√≥n \(\phi=\phi(x,t)\) de EOH es radial \(K\) iff $(Ax,t)=(x,t) $ por cada movimiento r√≠gido \(A\in SO(3)\) en las variables espaciales \(x,y,z\) de \(K\). Impl√≠citamente esto requiere una representaci√≥n de grupo de Lie \(\rho\) de \(SO(3)\) en el grupo de Lorentz \(G\simeq O(3,1)\). Pero esta elecci√≥n de subgrupo compacto m√°ximo no es can√≥nica. Diferentes observadores inerciales \(K, K'\) generalmente eligen diferentes grupos de simetr√≠a ortogonal, p.¬†seg√∫n su propia f√≥rmula f√≠sica de suma de cuadrados \(\xi^2+\eta^2+\zeta^2\).
Por supuesto, la forma de Minkowski \(h\) es invariante y can√≥nica, pero cualquier descomposici√≥n en componentes ‚Äúespaciales‚Äù y ‚Äútemporales‚Äù requiere elecciones arbitrarias dependientes del observador, y estas elecciones no pueden ser invariantes de Lorentz.
Por ejemplo, mientras que el conjunto abierto de vectores temporales \(\{h(v) < 0\}\) se define invariablemente, no hay una elecci√≥n invariante de Lorentz de vector temporal. Del mismo modo, entre el conjunto espacial \(\{h(v)>0\}\) no hay una elecci√≥n invariante de Lorentz de un marco tridimensional ortogonal.
Adem√°s, para el movimiento de los pulsos de luz seg√∫n (A12), el elemento de Minkowski se anula de forma id√©ntica y el √∫nico elemento tensor can√≥nico se convierte en el elemento cero constante. Despu√©s de un cambio de variables de Lorentz, encontramos una nueva soluci√≥n \(\phi'\) como la anterior, pero esta soluci√≥n no necesita ser radial en el marco inercial \(K'\). De hecho, el movimiento espacial \(K\) r√≠gido \(A\) generalmente no preservar√° las coordenadas espaciales \(\xi, \eta, \zeta\) de \(K'\). Por lo tanto, encontramos que los movimientos de \(A\) dependen de manera no trivial de la variable de tiempo \(K'\) \(\tau\). Esto nuevamente refleja la inexistencia de un radio invariante de Lorentz.


Conclusi√≥n
Esto concluye nuestro an√°lisis matem√°tico de los fundamentos de la RS, especialmente los Supuestos de Einstein (A12) y su intento de resoluci√≥n a trav√©s de las f√≥rmulas de Lorentz y las afirmaciones (i) y (ii).
En √∫ltima instancia, las transformaciones de Lorentz no tienen las propiedades necesarias para mantener (A12). La llamada Ley de Propagaci√≥n de la Luz (A2) no es una ley invariante de Lorentz, y por lo tanto no satisface por s√≠ misma el Principio de Relatividad Restringida como lo supone Einstein en su Suposici√≥n (A1).
En nuestra Parte 4 final de esta serie, presentamos algunas posibles objeciones a nuestros argumentos e intentamos anticipar algunas cr√≠ticas. Sin embargo, debemos mantener que todos los argumentos anteriores son matem√°ticamente correctos. title: Foundations of Special Relativity and Light Propagation in Vacuum. A Critical Review (2/4).
text:
In Part 2/4 of our critical review of SR we discuss the errors in Einstein‚Äôs famous spherical wavefront proof. Ultimately we argue that the Law of Propagation of Light (A2) is not Lorentz invariant, contrary to Einstein‚Äôs claims. The error is subtle.

Apparent Difficulties in SR and Einstein‚Äôs Attempted Resolution
In the previous article (Part 1/4) we reviewed the basic assumptions of SR, represented in assumptions we call (A1) and (A2).

(A1) that the laws of physics are the same in all nonaccelerated reference frames, i.e.¬†if \(K'\) is a coordinate system moving uniformly (and devoid of rotation) with respect to a coordinate system \(K\), then natural phenomena run their course with respect to \(K'\) according to exactly the same laws as with respect to \(K\).
(A2) that light in vacuum propagates along straight lines with constant velocity \(c = 300,000 ~km/sec\).

The conjunction \((A12):=(A1) \wedge (A2)\) leads to intellectual difficulties, as Einstein himself admits. But these difficulties are only apparent incompatibilities according to Einstein which are resolved by postulating the Lorentz transformations. The assertion that Lorentz formulae resolve all apparent difficulties in (A12) follows from two claims:

Claim (i): that inertial frames \(K, K'\) are related by Lorentz transformations.
Claim (ii): that the law of propagation of light (A2) is Lorentz invariant. I.e. if (A2) is satisfied in \(K\) , then (A2) is satisfied in every Lorentz translate \(K‚Ä≤=\lambda.K\).

The key issue is verifying whether (A2) really follows from the Claims (i) and (ii). This is the subject of Einstein‚Äôs spherical wave front argument which we examine below.


Critique of Einstein‚Äôs Proof of the Compatibility of (A12) with Lorentz Transformations
We were led to reviewing Einstein‚Äôs SR by reading the articles of S.J. Crothers and R. Bryant, which allege that Einstein‚Äôs spherical wave proof contains significant errors.
Einstein‚Äôs argument looks to derive Claim (ii) as a mathematical consequence of Claim (i). The starting point is the fundamental property of Lorentz transformations, that the quadratic expression \[x^2+y^2+z^2 = c^2 t^2\] is invariant with respect to Lorentz transforms. In other words, the null cone \(N\) is Lorentz covariant. Thus if \[(\xi, \eta, \zeta, \tau)=\lambda. (x,y,z,t)\] for a Lorentz transform \(\lambda\), then we have

[Eq1] \[\xi^2 + \eta^2+\zeta^2 = c^2 \tau^2.\]

But what does the expression [Eq1] represent?
Here is Einstein‚Äôs first error: his argument misidentifies [Eq1] with ‚Äúthe equation of a sphere.‚Äù The error is subtle. But the fact is that [Eq1] is strictly speaking a three-dimensional cone in the four independant variables \(\xi, \eta, \zeta, \tau\). The cone indeed contains many spherical two-dimensional subsets, but our point is that a second independant equation is necessary to specify these spheres. And these independant equations cannot be chosen Lorent invariantly!
Penrose in his textbook with Rindler is quite careful here. The Penrose approach is to projectivize [Eq1] and obtain a projective sphere with a uniquely defined Lorentz invariant conformal structure.
But again we must emphasize that there is no canonical metric invariant with respect to the Lorentz group on the projectivization. In otherwords, the null sphere has a Lorentz invariant conformal structure, but it does not have a Lorentz invariant Riemannian structure.
For instance the standard round sphere \(S\) centred at the origin simultaneously satisfies [Eq1] and additionally the equation \[\frac{1}{2}d(\xi^2+\eta^2+\zeta^2)=\xi d\xi+\eta d\eta +\zeta d\zeta=0.\] In short, the round sphere requires that two quadratic forms \(\xi^2+\eta^2+\zeta^2\) and \(c^2\tau^2\) be simultaneously constant.
This leads us to Einstein‚Äôs second error, which is the failure to observe that the Lorentz invariance of the quadratic form \(h=x^2+y^2+z^2-c^2t^2\) in no way implies the Lorentz invariance of \(h_1:=x^2+y^2+z^2\) and \(h_2:=c^2 t^2\).
Indeed the quadratic forms \(h_1, h_2\) are degenerate, with nontrivial radicals \(rad(h_1)=\{x=y=z=0\}\) and \(rad(h_2)=\{t=0\}.\) The radicals are linear subspaces of \({\bf{R}}^4\). But if \(h_1, h_2\) are invariant, then \(rad(h_1)\) and \(rad(h_2)\) are also nontrivial invariant subspaces. This contradicts the fact that the standard linear representation of the Lorentz group acts irreducibly on \({\bf{R}}^4\).
To summarize the two errors in Einstein‚Äôs famous argument:

the cone \(\xi^2 + \eta^2+\zeta^2 = c^2 \tau^2\) is misidentified as the equation of a sphere.
the Lorentz invariance of \(\xi^2 + \eta^2+\zeta^2 = c^2 \tau^2\) does not imply the Lorentz invariance of the forms \(\xi^2 + \eta^2+\zeta^2\) and \(c^2 \tau^2\).

In otherwords, the numerical equality between \(\xi^2 + \eta^2+\zeta^2\) and \(c^2\tau^2\) is always maintained, but the actual values attained by the expressions is not Lorentz invariant.
We are repeating ourselves because this is somewhat subtle point which is easily overlooked.


Elementary Computations in \({\bf{R}}^{1,1}\)
To illustrate the above ideas, it‚Äôs convenient to examine some elementary computations in two variables. Thus we consider \({\bf{R}^2}\) with \((x,t)\) and \((\xi, \tau)\) coordinates.
For numerical convenience we set \(c:=1\).
Thus \(h=x^2-t^2\) is a quadratic form on \({\bf{R}}^2\) invariant with respect to the one-dimensional Lorentz group \(G=SO(1,1)_0\) generated by \[a_\theta:=\begin{pmatrix} \cosh \theta & \sinh \theta \\
\sinh \theta & \cosh \theta
\end{pmatrix}\] for \(\theta\in {\bf{R}}\).
In two dimensions the null cone \[N=\{x^2-t^2=0\}\] projectivizes to a \(0\)-dimensional sphere consisting of two projective points represented by the affine lines \(x-t=0\) and \(x+t=0\).
The round \(0\)-dimensional sphere \(\{x^2=1\}\) consists of two vectors in the null cone, namely \[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1\end{pmatrix}, ~~~\begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 1\end{pmatrix}.\]
Left translating these vectors by \(a_\theta\) we find the translates \[\begin{pmatrix} \xi \\ \tau \end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix} \cosh \theta+\sinh \theta \\ \cosh \theta+\sinh \theta \end{pmatrix}~~\text{and} \begin{pmatrix} -\cosh \theta+\sinh \theta \\ \cosh \theta-\sinh \theta \end{pmatrix}.\]
But evidently \[\xi^2 \neq x^2=1^2=1\] and \[\tau^2 \neq t^2=1\] when \(\theta\neq 0\). Thus the quadratic forms \(h_1=x^2\) and \(h_2=t^2\) are not \(a_\theta\)-invariant. Likewise we find the image of the unit sphere \(x^2=1\) does not correspond to a spatial sphere in \((\xi, \tau)\) coordinates.
These trivial computations have the effect of falsifying the alleged Lorentz invariance of spherical lightwaves. However the ‚Äúslope‚Äù of \(\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1\end{pmatrix}\) and \[a_\theta.\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1\end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix} \cosh \theta+\sinh \theta \\ \cosh \theta+\sinh \theta \end{pmatrix}\] is identically equal to \(c=1\) in accordance with (A2).
To further illustrate earlier comments on the nonexistence of canonical parameters on \(N\), consider that for any \(C^1\) monotonic function \[ f: {\bf{R}} \to {\bf{R}} \] we obtain a curve \[\epsilon(t)=\epsilon_f(t)=\begin{pmatrix} f(t) \\ f(t)   \end{pmatrix}=f(t) \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}\] for \(t\in {\bf{R}}\).
Then \(\epsilon_f(t)\) is supported on a straight line in \(N\), and the ‚Äúphoton‚Äù \(\epsilon_f\) can be said to propagate in a straight line with constant speed \(c=1\).
It might be said that \(\epsilon_f\) is not uniform in the parameter \(t\), but we argue that there exists no Lorentz invariant definition of ‚Äúuniform parameter‚Äù on the null cone.
This is related to our discussion in Part 1 on Levi-Civita‚Äôs attempt to derive a geodesic equation for light propagation, i.e.¬†the hypothesis that light travels with zero acceleration. We reasoned that this is an arbitrary additional hypothesis, and not a consequence of the formal assumptions (A12).
In the remaining Parts 3/4 and 4/4 of this article, we consider the homogeneous wave equations and Lorentz transformations. As we have previously indicated, we find (A12) incompatible with both the wave and particle models of light.

title: Modified Fizeau Sansbury Spinning Wheel Experiment
text:
In this post we discuss our modified Fizeau-Sansbury spinning sawtooth experiment. To begin we review Fizeau‚Äôs original 1849 experiment and introduce our modification which allows for testing R. Sansbury‚Äôs apparatus. While Fizeau studies a saw tooth wheel in uniform motion on the order of twenty rotations per second, Sansbury‚Äôs setup can be interpreted as either the same wheel in nonuniform motion, or a wheel with variable saw tooth length in uniform motion. We argue that Sansbury‚Äôs predictions could be tested if Fizeau‚Äôs wheel could increase it‚Äôs angular velocity from 20 revolutions per second, to 80 revolutions or 160 revolutions per second. This is not easily realized.
As described in previous posts, our critical essay on foundations in SR is basically stable and readable. Here we begin to elaborate on the concluding section, which briefly mentions Ralph Sansbury‚Äôs proposed experiment. Sansbury‚Äôs experiment is this. We take \(c\) the speed of light as equal to \(1\) foot per nanosecond \([\mu s]=10^{-8}\) seconds.

Sansbury‚Äôs Experiment
We quote from Sansbury‚Äôs paper and his book ‚ÄúFaster than Light‚Äù.
(Case 1) A \(15\) nanosecond light pulse from a laser was sent to a light detector, \(30\) feet away. When the light pulse was blocked at the photodiode during the time of emission, but unblocked at the expected time of arrival, \(31.2\) nanoseconds after the beginning of the time of emission, for \(15\) nanosecond duration, little light was received. (A little more than the \(4mV\) noise on the oscilloscope). This process was repeated thousands of times per second.
(Case 2) When the light was unblocked at the photodiode during the time of emission (\(15\) nanoseconds) but blocked after the beginning of the time of emission, during the expected time of arrival for \(15\) nanoseconds, twice as much light was received (\(8mV\)). This process was repeated thousands of times per second.
Sansbury‚Äôs conclusion? That this indicated that light is not a moving wave or photon, but rather the cumulative effect of instantaneous forces at a distance. That is, undetectable oscillations of charge can occur in the atomic nuclei of the photodiode that spill over as detectable oscillations of electrons after a delay.
Sansbury found the equipment necessary for the experiment too expensive to rent for an extended period of time, and he was possibly not a sufficient expert in calibrating the equipment. So Sansbury‚Äôs experiment appears to have not been sufficiently investigated, and we would argue that the experiment has neither been reproduced nor properly reviewed. Thus we turn to the classical Fizeau experiment, and consider its similarities to Sansbury‚Äôs setup.


Fizeau‚Äôs Saw Tooth Experiment (1849)
Now Sansbury‚Äôs apparatus has some similarity with Fizeau‚Äôs sawtooth apparatus, as used circa 1849 to prove some of the first sensible measurements of luminal velocity.
Here is a blog which inlcudes a transcription of Fizeau‚Äôs original 1849 paper in Comptes Rendus.
Here is an interesting youtube video en francais sur la mesure de Fizeau. Around the 4-5 minute mark is the most interesting. While the speed of the wheel is increased, the received light signal becomes increasingly erratic and intermittent, until a sufficiently high speed of rotation is achieved and the received light signal becomes eventually null and no light is received.
Here is a useful physics stackexchange answer.


Sansbury vs.¬†Fizeau
Now Fizeau‚Äôs original setup is a type of Sansbury test where the wheel is in uniform motion. Sansbury‚Äôs setup involves either a wheel in nonuniform motion, or equivalently a wheel in uniform motion with a nonuniform sawtooth distribution.
We remark that Fizeau was historically looking to estimate the luminal velocity \(c\). Sansbury‚Äôs experiment assumes \(c\) as given, estimated at \(1\) foot per nanosecond. Sansbury‚Äôs goal is to distinguish light propagation from particle model, and his setup is meant to test whether light is even something that travels at all.
Let‚Äôs review the basic math of Fizeau‚Äôs apparatus, it‚Äôs very simple. No matter how we setup the mirrors, we suppose light has some total travel time. In Fizeau‚Äôs original setup, light travelled a total path of \(\approx 16 km\). With an expected speed of light \(c=3\times 10^8 km\), then the expected travel time is
\[\begin{equation}
\frac{16 \times 10^3 [m]}{3 \times 10^8 [m]/[sec]}=5.333\ldots \times 10^{-5} [sec].\end{equation}\]
Now consider the wheel with angular velocity \(\omega\) having units of \([degrees]/[sec]\) and having a toothlength equal to \(1/720\) degrees. The time required to turn one toothlength is therefore \(\frac{1/720}{\omega}=\frac{1}{720 \omega} [sec]\). Thus we find that the expected travel time is equal to the time to rotate one toothlength if the following equality holds \[\frac{16 \times 10^3 }{3 \times 10^8} = \frac{1}{720 \omega}, \] which implies \[\omega \approx 26 ~~~\frac{[rotations]}{[sec]}.\]
Sansbury‚Äôs (Case 1) could be realized if the wheel was allowed to rotate nonuniformly, i.e.¬†if the wheel could be accelerated in ‚Äúimpulses‚Äù something closer to the actual discrete motions of a clock. For example, if the wheel is initially opened at the time of emission, then immediately rotated one saw tooth length (to the closed position) during the expected time of travel, and just prior to the expected time of arrival is rotated another tooth length (to the open position), then Fizeau would predict that the receiver would observe a strong light source. However Sansbury predicts that the receiver would observe rather a very weak signal. Notice here we require the wheel to move twice as fast as Fizeau‚Äôs angular velocity. In otherwords the wheel must rotate two complete tooth lengths before the estimated arrival time.
Sansbury‚Äôs (Case 2) could be realized if the wheel was rotating nonuniformly. For example, if we keep the wheel fixed during the expected time of flight of the light particle, and turn the wheel one complete toothlength at the expected time of arrival, then Sansbury would predict a relatively strong signal would be received. Fizeau and the particle model would however predict no light would be received, since in the model it would be blocked by the sawtooth at the expected time of arrival.
N.B. Fizeau‚Äôs conception of the sawtooth wheel is classical. But what happens if we retrospectively apply the SR methodology to the experiment, what results are obtained? It appears that SR has a null effect on the entire experiment, i.e.¬†returns the same results as the classical case. While the sawteeth lengths are contracting in SR, this effects the circumference of the wheel but not the angular velocity. Thus Fizeau experiment appears insensitive to any Lorentz SR effects and an experiment which cannot prove SR in contrast to the classical mechanics.
We do not require mathematics at this stage, but rather to perform an experiment. However there is an intersting math aspect to the question, ‚ÄúHow to keep a nonuniform wheel in uniform motion?‚Äù.
Fizeau‚Äôs original wheel was materially balanced: the distribution of teeth was equidistant and regular. The centre of mass corresponded with the axis of rotation.
But if we begin to study nonuniform wheels, then the behaviour becomes more difficult depending on, say, whether the centre of mass coincides with the axis of rotation.
Some comparisons between Fizeau and Sansbury:

Fizeau‚Äôs involves several reflecting mirrors (beam splitters). Therefore there is more interaction involved in Fizeau‚Äôs setup than with Sansbury‚Äôs. For Fizeau‚Äôs is a type of two-way trip of light, where the source and receiver are space-coincident. But Sansbury‚Äôs is a one-way trip, requiring some electronics at the receiver namely a photodiode, to measure the amount of electrons released by the light emission.
If the phase of Fizeau‚Äôs wheel could be controlled, then we could compare the behaviour of the experiment when the wheels differ by one saw tooth length. The trouble in Fizeau is that, because the source and receiver coincide, it‚Äôs evident that no light is emitted when the phase is shifted one tooth length. Sansbury‚Äôs experiment however does emphatically require the apparatus to be open at the moment of emission.



Faster Fizeau Wheels
We could test some of Sansbury‚Äôs ideas if we could increase the angular velocity of the Fizeau wheel by factor of \(4\), i.e.¬†we need a wheel of roughly \(100\) revolutions per second instead of \(20\) revolutions per second.
Given such a revolution speed, then we could change the sawtooth pattern of the wheels, having some that are \(1/4\) closed, \(1/2\) closed, and \(3/4\) closed wheels. For example, we could have the alternating sawtooth \[\ldots 0101010101 \ldots\] or we could have \[\ldots 001100110011 \ldots\] both of which are \(1/2\) closed but having different patterns. And these patterns would have different predictions depending on the photon model or Sansbury‚Äôs cumulative action-at-a-distance. Likewise it would be interesting to compare the predictions given a wheel having a \(1/4\)-closed sawtooth pattern \[\ldots 0001000100010001 \ldots\] versus a \(3/4\)-closed pattern \[ \ldots 0111011101110111\ldots.\]
If we could get the Fizeau wheel to spin \(200\) revolutions per second, then we could test the theories according to \(8\)-periodic patterns, i.e.¬†with sawtooth patterns being \(1/8, 2/8\), \(\ldots\), \(7/8\)ths closed.
If we could build a larger wheel with more teeth, say, \(1440\) teeth, then \(2880\) teeth, then basic gear ratio would increase the speed of the initial pinion wheel by factor of \(\times 2\), \(\times 4\), etc..
The heuristics by which we can determine reasonable revolutions per second depends probably on some energy estimates and would require smaller and smaller radii.
[To be continued‚Ä¶]
